message: Wishing everyone in the Fifth District a very happy New Year. In 2017, I look forward to serving and representing you in the 115th Congress so that we can continue to expand access to opportunities that help all hardworking Chicagoans and Americans get ahead.

Good government is rooted in openness, honesty and integrity, and the independent Office of Congressional Ethics plays a critical role in upholding these fundamental values. It is shameful that House Republicans are seeking to enhance one-party rule by undermining this non-partisan panel through a secret Caucus vote held behind closed doors. This move sends a dangerous and distressing message to the American people at the start of a new Congress, especially following empty promises to “drain the swamp.” We must continue to shine a light on the halls of our government so that we do not return to darker days plagued by unreported scandals and overlooked ethics violations that weaken our democratic institutions.

Today, I shared a letter from Mary, a constituent in the Fifth District who is fearful about what repealing the Affordable Care Act would mean for her son who has Addison’s Disease and relies on ACA for quality, affordable care. Republicans talk about “repeal and replace,” but what that really means is “repeal and go back to before,” back to a time when 47 million Americans—nearly 18% of the population—were uninsured. On behalf of Mary’s son and other Americans in districts across the country, I urge my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to abandon their efforts to strip health care from those who need it, and instead work with us to make our country a healthier place for all.

A New Year, a new Congress, but the same ideological attacks against women’s health care by House Republicans. We cannot and should not start the 115th Congress with renewed partisan promises to gut comprehensive, preventative and affordable care for women. From birth control and STD testing to cervical screenings, mammograms, and counseling, Planned Parenthood is a critical resource for Chicagoans and others in communities across the country. View my thoughts on Speaker Ryan's comments about defunding Planned Parenthood:

Please read my op-ed in The Hill on how Republicans’ scuttled vote to weaken our ethics watchdog hurts efforts to win back public trust. As co-founder and co-chair of the Transparency Caucus, I understand that an individual cannot be an effective leader without trust. I hope this week’s vote is not a sign of things to come – We should be increasing transparency and accountability, not further chipping away at good governance or eroding the foundations of our democratic institutions. http://bit.ly/2hY6UHP

In addition to stripping quality, affordable care from up to 20 million Americans, repealing the Affordable Care Act without a replacement would also harm our economy, triggering major reductions in employment to the tune of nearly three million jobs by 2021. This number includes 114,000 jobs that would be lost right here in Illinois. View the full report here: http://bit.ly/2iQz9bk

Public transit like Chicago Transit Authority is good for our city, our citizens, and our environment, which is why I was pleased to join in announcing a $1 billion funding agreement today that will allow the CTA to move forward with the first phase of the Red and Purple Modernization Program (RPM) to improve service. I look forward to supporting RPM and other important infrastructure improvements in Congress to enhance quality of life for Chicagoans and spur economic development in the region.

This morning I spoke with over 200 students at Alcott College Prep Elementary School, including several students who will be traveling to Washington, D.C. for the presidential inauguration with tickets from my office. It’s never too early to teach young people the importance of participating in our democracy through political engagement, and I am honored to have the opportunity to offer Fifth District students a front-row seat to this historic civics lesson in our nation’s capital.

I am honored to be chosen by my colleagues as a new Vice-Chair of the House Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition As Vice-Chair, I remain committed to working with my colleagues in SEEC to preserve clean air, clean water, and healthy ecosystems, which are vital to ensuring robust and sustained economic growth and protecting a world we are proud to hand to our children and grandchildren. This life-saving work is more important than ever. http://bit.ly/2j51D16

Today, I spoke on the House Floor about the need for robust, long-term investment in our infrastructure to improve quality of life and spur economic growth. I urge the 115th Congress to prioritize infrastructure spending that addresses America’s roadways but also goes beyond roads and bridges to include all aspects of our connected infrastructure system that makes America the best place to live on earth.

What I'm Reading: "I Abstained From Sex for a Year to Donate Blood" via Jay Franzone in The New York Times http://nyti.ms/2jb9kCp   It has been a privilege to work with Jay on this critical issue, and I applaud him for his leadership and commitment. Our nation's blood donation deferral policy for gay men requires a 12-month deferral, or celibacy, period before being able to donate blood. This blood ban is discriminatory and outdated. All healthy Americans who want to help save lives through blood donation should be given the opportunity, and I will continue my efforts in Congress to end this ban and ensure our policies are rooted in science, not stigma.

This weekend, I was able to get out on the ice and coach some eager beginners with help from the USA Warriors Ice Hockey and the #HockeyOnYourBlock program, which opens up the sport to kids who might otherwise not be able to play by providing free equipment, ice time and instruction. I was also able to participate in a fun game this morning with the Warriors players and Chicago Blackhawks alum to benefit our nation's veterans. Always great to be out on the ice with you guys!

Today, we celebrate the life, work and leadership of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. His passion and humility in leading the way for civil rights, workers' rights, and equality is an example we must all continue to follow as we strive for respect, inclusion and progress of all people. His legacy is etched in the minds of all of us and will never be forgotten.
Joined Chicago's World Series Champions the Chicago Cubs for a special celebration at the The White House with President Obama this morning. A great way to celebrate two great legacies. Go Cubs go!

Today I joined The Night Ministry, a Chicago-based organization that works to provide housing, health care and human connection to members of the community struggling with poverty or homelessness. Hearing personal stories from some of the most vulnerable in our society, as well as testimonies from dedicated Night Ministry team members, brought to light some of the serious struggles Chicagoans face every day. I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues in Congress to address the causes of these challenges and find meaningful solutions.

Just a few highlights from the Trump Administration’s likely budget proposal:   • Cutting critical funding and programs in the departments of Transportation, Justice and State. • Eliminating the National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities. • Privatizing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. • Scrapping Violence Against Women Grants and the Office of Community Oriented Policing Services. • Reducing funding for Legal Services Corporation’s Civil Rights and Environment and Natural Resources divisions. • Ending the Minority Business Development Agency and the Manufacturing Extension Partnership. • Eradicating the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy and funding for the Paris Climate Change Agreement.   http://bit.ly/2k4S3YI

This week, I was proud to present two outstanding students in the Fifth District with Congressional Award Medals. The Congressional Award program honors students for achievements in volunteer public service, personal developments, physical fitness and expedition and exploration. I congratulate Meral Betul Aycicek and Olivia Kupiec on their accomplishments and wish them well in the bright futures that await them.

I enjoyed spending my afternoon volunteering at the Lakeview Pantry, where I assisted in distributing food and goods to those in need. I thank the pantry staff for their passion, service and dedicated efforts to eliminate poverty and hunger in our community, as well as for the opportunity to join them in giving back.

The Office of Congressman Mike Quigley regrets to inform its constituents and followers that the Congressman's brother, Dan, passed away unexpectedly yesterday. There will be a pause in social media posting today with more information to come. Thank you.

Congressman Quigley thanks everyone for their kind thoughts and prayers following the loss of his brother, Dan.  Your condolences have been very much appreciated by the Congressman as he returns to Washington, D.C. for session today.

Are you in the Elmwood Park area? My staff will have visiting office hours at the Elmwood Park Public Village Hall tomorrow, January 25th, from 2 p.m. until 4 p.m. Please stop by if you need help with a federal issue -- Medicare, Social Security, or otherwise.

Two days after the 44th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, three days after millions of women joined around the world in support of reproductive rights, and just four days after President Trump was sworn into office, my Republican colleagues have chosen to focus their attention on attacking abortion access. H.R.7 is dangerous, all-encompassing legislation that punishes women by making abortion coverage bans permanent law. I will continue to challenge these partisan actions to ensure women are free from government interference and have the right to make the private health and family planning decisions that work best for them. (photo credit: DNAInfo)

Banning the EPA and U.S. Department of Agriculture from issuing updates in the form of press releases, social media, blog posts, and other public facing documents clearly signifies the Trump Administration’s dangerous and deliberate shift towards a closed government. This media blackout strips the American people of the access and resources needed to monitor the actions of those who represent them in government, hindering public trust, stifling discourse and encouraging a lack of transparency.   We can't allow the Trump Administration to silence science. I will continue my efforts to ensure scientific facts are acknowledged by lawmakers, utilized in policymaking, and shared with constituents. http://bit.ly/2jpEoOB

Gun violence is a national tragedy that requires immediate and substantial action, but President Trump’s threat to “send in the Feds” to fix the “carnage” in Chicago is reckless, misguided, and a gross overreach of federal power. Instead, the President should work with Congress to support our first responders, advance commonsense gun legislation, and establish a budget that restores funding for critical Department of Justice and Department of Homeland Security programs that have been severely cut by Republican lawmakers.

President Trump’s executive order stripping funding from Sanctuary Cities is unconstitutional and harmful – not only to our vulnerable immigrant communities, but to all Americans living in these cities. It is essential that we stand in solidarity with immigrants seeking security and safety in Chicago and across the country.

What I Am Reading: Insightful article from POLITICO editor Susan B. Glasser on how reporters can cover government and politics in an emerging "post-truth" era fueled by limited press access, the rise of fake news, and the creation of alternative facts. "Share" or "like" to remind the Trump Administration that "alternative facts" are not facts, but lies.

President Trump's executive order creating a Muslim ban undermines our ideals as a nation founded by immigrants. I call on the Administration to immediately rescind this shameful order, which is already presenting very real and dangerous consequences around the globe. Religious freedom is essential to who we are as Americans and the suggestion that one religious group should be favored over others by our government is unacceptable.    "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses, yearning to breathe free." These words are emblazoned on the Statue of Liberty–a universal symbol of freedom, friendship and the gateway for millions of immigrants throughout our history. Today, these words take on a new urgency in the face of the Trump Administration's immoral actions.   https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/28/us/refugees-detained-at-us-airports-prompting-legal-challenges-to-trumps-immigration-order.html?_r=0

The elevation of White House Chief Strategist, Steve Bannon, to a permanent position on the National Security Council should be deeply troubling to all Americans concerned with the safety and security of our nation. White nationalist convictions fueled by an anti-globalist agenda has no place in our foreign or national security policy. As a member of the House Intelligence Committee, I know firsthand that our approach to national security issues are the matter of life and death. These tough calls must be made by experts relying on sound judgment, intelligence and experience; and we cannot allow this critical decision-making process to be muddled by efforts to push partisan or political motives. Read my full statement here: http://bit.ly/2jLtVNo

Today, I was proud to introduce the Safeguarding Sanctuary Cities Act, legislation to ensure that federal funds cannot be unduly withheld from cities protecting immigrants seeking safety, security, and the American Dream. We must use the vast resources at our disposal to advance comprehensive immigration reform, not President Trump's push for coercive funding conditions, which are ineffective and harmful to anyone living in a ‘sanctuary’ city—citizen or not. I am not the only member of Congress who was appalled by President Trump's threat to defund sanctuary cities, and I am pleased to have dozens of my Democratic colleagues join me on this bill to protect the immigrant communities that help make our nation great.

TODAY is the last day to sign up for quality, affordable health care for 2017. Unfortunately, the Trump Administration has ended outreach and canceled ACA advertisements, even while the law is currently serving millions of American families across the nation. Therefore, I’d like to encourage you here to visit HealthCare.gov today to explore plans, compare your options, and #GetCovered.

Last night, President Trump ignored an opportunity to repair the division and damage caused in just the first two weeks of his administration. Instead of choosing a moderate, independent judge to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, he chose Judge Gorsuch, whose past rulings are in stark contrast with where the majority of Americans stand on the issues facing our nation. We must hold Judge Gorsuch accountable to his legal record, which in too many instances has failed hardworking Americans across the country. Read my full statement: http://bit.ly/2kSfLZF

Today, I spoke on the House Floor about President Trump's misguided, counterproductive, and objectively anti-American executive order banning refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S. Unfortunately, this is not the first time we have turned away innocent people seeking safety in our country, but it is up to us to learn from the mistakes of our past. View my thoughts on how this ban undermines our values and makes us less safe:

In the fast-paced, evolving media coverage of the new administration, it's hard to remember what outrageous claim or attack President Donald Trump made and when. Unfortunately, despite the onslaught of offenses and barrage of new policies coming from the Oval Office, we must continue to hold the president accountable for each and every action intended to roll back progress, safety or opportunity for American families—from sweeping executive orders to 140-character tweets.  Please read my op-ed on President Trump’s misguided threat to "send in the Feds" to address gun violence in Chicago. When Trump attacks our city, he is not attacking our elevated rates of violence. He is attacking the people who live here.

These words take on new meaning in the Trump Administration, which is why I was pleased to join Rep. Darrell Issa yesterday in hosting our first bipartisan Transparency Caucus briefing of the 115th Congress on the topic of web harvesting. In this increasingly digital age, it is essential that we archive government data to help us make informed policy decisions rooted in facts and evidence. I am particularly concerned about what this lack of preservation means for scientific data under an Administration that pushes “alternative facts” and a president who is also an avid climate change skeptic. Read more: http://bit.ly/2jZPqKN

This week marked the beginning of Black History Month, a celebration of those who have strengthened American culture in every way. From those who braved violence or death to escape slavery to those who marched on Washington to all of the teachers, entrepreneurs, service members, and community leaders of today –  we are forever grateful. This February, and every month, let us honor these great contributions by recommitting ourselves to the important work that remains to preserve justice, equality, and opportunity for all. We can do so by restoring voter protections, improving workers rights, addressing failings within our criminal justice system, defending access to quality health care, and creating more good-paying jobs.

Our democracy not only depends on our participation in the democratic process, but also on the promise that our participation allows the voice of the people to be truly heard. As Illinois’ only Member on the House Intelligence Committee, I am committed to guaranteeing that our future elections are free, fair and conducted without interference. Check out my Chicago Tribune op-ed “Why Russian Hacking Matters” on the importance of a bipartisan, through investigation to ensure Russia never undermines our democracy again.

Nearly 450 former Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) employees have urged Congress to reject President Trump’s nominee to run the agency, Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt. His open skepticism of climate change and its fossil fuel ties are dangerous for the well-being of Americans and devastating for our environment. I hope Mr. Pruitt will respond to my invitation to discuss and debate this incredibly important issue, so that we can continue taking the steps needed to support an environmentally sustainable future for generations to come.

I am proud to be appointed as the new Ranking Member of the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee, where I will remain committed to securing the investments needed to protect consumers, promote small business, and strengthen our financial system. The FSGG Appropriations Subcommittee is responsible for providing oversight and approval over annual spending levels for a diverse number of agencies, including the IRS, the SEC, the Small Business Administration, the Judiciary, and the FCC.   As we begin what will undoubtedly be a very difficult appropriations season, I will fight to ensure that agencies have the resources and tools they need to adequately serve the American people, as well as defend the central pillars of Dodd-Frank from unnecessary partisan attacks. We must always put working people before Wall Street, and I will hold the President and Republicans in Congress accountable for any actions that suggest otherwise. http://bit.ly/2lh4o0Q

President Trump has made a lot of disparaging remarks about Chicago, but his comments today claiming that Chicago’s gun violence is the result of undocumented immigrants represent one his most misguided statements yet. Until the President actually proposes pragmatic solutions to help our city, it is very clear that his attacks are nothing more than empty, partisan rhetoric.

I was pleased to attend the annual LGBTQ Leadership Breakfast this morning, an event I look forward to all year. Unfortunately, in just the first month of the Trump Administration, we’ve already seen proposals circulating the White House to weaken protections shielding LGBT individuals from discrimination, under the veil of religious freedom. Today, I addressed those concerns and fears, but also reiterated our strong message to the President: The American people will continue to be unrelenting in our efforts to stand up, speak out, and defend our rights from partisan, political attacks. As Vice Chair of the LGBT Equality Caucus, I will work my Democratic colleagues to hold President Trump accountable and ensure that no American is denied the pursuit of life, liberty, and happiness.

Last Friday, during Shabbat, the oldest synagogue in downtown Chicago was the site of a cowardly and heartbreaking attack, which unfortunately, will be added to the growing list of hate crime incidences across our nation. Yesterday, I was pleased visited the Chicago Loop Synagogue for an interfaith gathering to show our support for the congregants directly affected by this hate crime. However, hate crimes like this one affect all Americans spanning every religion, region, and walk of life. Every individual deserves the opportunity—and has the constitutional right—to worship how and where he or she chooses without fear. Much more work remains to eradicate the prejudices that jeopardize our safety and undermine our values.

Earlier this week, I met with some amazing Budlong Elementary School students who made hand-crafted valentines for our courageous veterans. It was my pleasure to deliver their kind messages to a few of our nation’s heroes at the Jesse Brown VA Medical Center. As always, I thanked them for their bravery, sacrifice, and service to our country.

Allegations that General Flynn had secret communications about sanctions with Russia’s ambassador—before Donald Trump took office—raises grave concerns about Mr. Flynn’s service in the Administration. If true, he not only breached protocol but mislead the American people, undermined our national security, and may have also broken the law. As a member of the House Intelligence Committee, we will continue our investigations into Russia's involvement in our democratic institutions, and these very alarming and concerning conversations must be included.

News of General Flynn’s resignation as National Security Advisor, a position he was never fit to hold, comes as no surprise. His secret conversations with the Russian Ambassador were disqualifying from the start and his resignation is appropriate and welcomed. Mr. Flynn undermined our national security the minute he picked up the phone, but what is just as troubling is that this serious wrongdoing and lapse of judgment in itself did not lead to Mr. Flynn’s termination. Instead, it required him to be caught in a lie to the President, Vice President and the American people. As a member of the House Intelligence Committee, I will continue to push for an immediate bicameral, bipartisan, and thorough investigation to disclose the full scope of the Administration’s involvement with those who hacked our democracy just months ago. http://nyti.ms/2kPlHof

The strengths of the nation can be seen in every corner of my district, where we celebrate the diversity, passion, and resilience of the people who live here, including those in our immigrant communities.   Today, I spoke on the House Floor about President Trump’s most recent, and most misguided, attack against my home city of Chicago. Contrary to his claim, elevated gun violence in Chicago does not stem from undocumented immigrants. Studies have long shown that immigration has no effect on crime rates, and researchers have found immigrants generally have the strongest incentives to avoid activity that will put them in contact with the criminal justice system. Instead of attacking the most vulnerable, the President should look for pragmatic, commonsense policies to support comprehensive immigration reform and gun violence prevention.

We cannot allow a lack of transparency to become standard operating procedure for the Trump Administration, resulting in more questions than answers for the American people. Phone records and intercepted calls from the campaign months preceding the election raise serious red flags, further demonstrating the critical need to investigate these activities.  Additionally, the President’s claim, as illustrated in this morning’s Twitter rant, that this new information is “non-sense” fueled by the failures of the media and intelligence community is both manipulative and dangerous. Only in this Administration are the “leaks’” more important than the truth. http://bit.ly/2lRBqkn

This week, I introduced the Botanical Sciences and Native Plant Materials Research, Restoration and Promotion Act to support the botanical science capacity of the federal government. One of our nation’s greatest assets is its biodiversity, which is why we must support the health of these ecosystems, as well as the dedicated scientists that have made our earth’s preservation their life’s work. I am pleased that this bill will support their mission to sustain native and locally adapted plants so that America remains a vibrant, inspiring, and sustainable place to call home. Read more about the bill here:

ICYMI: I joined CNN Newsroom this morning to discuss how a post-truth, post-science, post-intelligence President is dangerous to our national security. I will continue to call on the White House and my Republican colleagues in Congress to cooperate with a bipartisan, thorough investigation into Russia so we can follow the facts where they lead us and provide answers to the American people.

Earlier this month, I had the great pleasure of nominating passionate and hardworking students from Illinois’ Fifth Congressional District for admission to the U.S. Service Academies for the graduating class of 2021. These institutions help train and equip the next generation of military leaders with the skills, education and experience they need to keep America safe. I thank these students for their willingness to serve our nation in uniform.

Trump’s first month in office has been tainted by chaos, conflict and controversy, involving the courts, the news media, Russia, "alternative facts," and numerous harmful executive orders like his Muslim ban. This President’s Day should serve as a reminder of how fragile our democracy truly is and the need to hold our President accountable for his actions.

Hatred has no place on the streets of our communities, in the halls of our government, or in our houses of worship. The devastating vandalism at a historic Jewish cemetery in St. Louis this past weekend should trouble every American, including those in the Administration. Additionally, this weekend’s wave of bomb threats targeting 11 Jewish community centers across the country is part of a disturbing trend, as JCCs in 26 states received almost 60 bomb threats last month alone. These threats not only attack our pledge to religious freedom but jeopardize our founding principles of equality, justice, and opportunity for all. President Trump must use his office to step up and not only condemn these anti-Semitic threats but work to address the hatred that fuels them, which will only spread in the face of silence. http://theatln.tc/2ljGXTd

It was a pleasure to meet with Ukrainian President Poroshenko to discuss continued efforts to strengthen Ukraine’s democracy, as well as the strategic US-Ukraine partnership. We must stand by our friends in Ukraine as they stay the course on what is undoubtedly a long road toward a stable democracy, and we can do our part by preserving and enhancing international sanctions against Russia. The Trump Administration’s consideration to remove sanctions on Russia is dangerous, misguided, and damages U.S. global credibility, as it shortsightedly eliminates any leverage we have on the Kremlin. If President Trump remains unwilling to stand up to Vladimir Putin and draw a tough line on Russia, then members of Congress must accept the fundamental responsibility to act. https://quigley.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/quigley-statement-meeting-president-poroshenko-ukraine

As if being a kid wasn't hard enough, President Trump wants to make it even harder for transgender students who are simply seeking a safe and supportive school community where they can learn, grow, and thrive.  All students, including those in the LGBT community, are protected by the Constitution and Title IX, regardless of this President’s attempt to abandon his campaign promise and undermine equality and security for all. As Vice Chair of the LGBT Equality Caucus and a founding member of the Transgender Equality Task Force, I will fight with everything I have to protect transgender children from the shameful and despicable attempts to strip away their rights.   This move is unnecessary, uncaring, and uncalled-for. Read my full statement on Trump Administration’s Title IX announcement here: http://bit.ly/2mg2Ml0

ICYMI: I shared an op-ed in POLITICO reflecting on my visit to Ukraine this week and how it compared with my last visit in 2014. After my meeting with with President Poroshenko, it is clear that Ukraine’s democrats are desperate for American leadership, but they fear that President Trump will abandon them to Moscow’s clutches. We must support Ukraine by holding the Administration accountable and ensuring they maintain a tough line on Russia. Read here: http://politi.co/2mt88sv

Every American—whether Democrat, Republican, or Independent—should be deeply concerned by recent reports detailing the Trump Administration’s attempt to minimize a need for an investigation into its Russian ties. Unfortunately, it is less than surprising that the Trump White House tried to pressure the FBI into making public statements that promote their agenda, at the expense of transparency, honesty, and national security. These reports only reiterate what I and other members on the House Intelligence Committee have been pushing for all along: a thorough, bipartisan, bicameral investigation into Russia’s interference in our election, as well as our President’s ties to Russia. The stakes are too high to play politics with our safety and security, and the American people deserve answers.

This weekend, I joined Chicagoans at the Stand Up for Transgender Rights rally, where the message to members of the LGBT community was clear: you are not alone. I am proud and honored to stand with you as we continue the fight for human rights.

Today, I was proud to introduce the PROTECT Immigration Act to block a key component of President Trump's January 25 executive order on immigration.   Asking local law enforcement to detain suspected undocumented immigrants is unproductive, unnecessary, and unsafe because it shifts their limited resources away from fighting serious crimes. Instead of disrupting community relations and fostering mistrust at the local level, the federal government must meet its responsibility to enforce immigration law and advance comprehensive reform that will benefit every city in our nation. Read more about my bill here: http://bit.ly/2lOEU8i

I was pleased to lead my Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition colleagues in sending a letter to Secretary of State Rex Tillerson following a recent public statement made by his successor as Chairman and CEO of ExxonMobil, Darren Woods, regarding the validity and urgency of climate change action. It is encouraging to read such sentiments from the leader of one of the world’s largest and most prominent fossil fuel companies, a company Secretary Tillerson oversaw just two months ago. Which is why it is imperative that Secretary Tillerson immediately acknowledge Mr. Woods' words and work to address the threats of climate change, which also pose serious risks to our national security.

In just over an hour, I will attend President Trump's first joint address to Congress with my guest Zarna Patel, a second-year medical student at Loyola University in Chicago and a Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program recipient.   Following the hateful and discriminatory words and actions we have seen from this Administration, it is more important now than ever to send a clear message to President Trump at tonight’s address: America is a nation of immigrants, and we will continue to stand with those seeking safety, security, and a better life in our country as we push for comprehensive immigration reform.  I thank Zarna for her dedication, passion, and hard work to become a primary care doctor helping undeserved communities in the great state of Illinois, which she calls home. http://bit.ly/2mH0Z84

President Trump’s joint address to Congress was long on rhetoric but short on details. We heard populist sound bites but no real policy initiatives that will advance economic opportunity for middle-class Americans, strengthen national security here at home, and build on the undeniable progress made during the past eight years. It is easier to attack affordable health care, our vulnerable immigrant communities, and cities struggling with gun violence than it is to advance bipartisan efforts that address the many challenges our country faces. But that is what we must do to move America forward. Read my full statement here:

It is both unconscionable and unacceptable that Attorney General Jeff Sessions, our nation’s top law enforcement official, lied under oath about his communications with the Russian Ambassador. It is clear that he must now not only recuse himself from participation in any Department of Justice investigation of contacts between the Trump campaign and Russian officials, but also resign from his role in the Administration. Unfortunately, reports of Session’s secret talks just add to the growing list of Trump campaign staff and Administration officials who held private conversations with members of the Russian government. This trend should concern all Americans, while strengthening the already solid, indisputable case for an independent, bipartisan investigation into the Trump Administration’s Russian ties. Read my full statement: http://bit.ly/2liaO05

Spoke at the Climate Leadership Conference in Chicago this morning about policy solutions to combat climate change and the important work my district is doing to support a clean energy economy. We must work together to enact common-sense legislation that makes our world a better, safer, and more sustainable place for Americans today and tomorrow.

ICYMI – A recap of presidential priorities: Trump's four weekend stays at Mar-a-Lago cost more than his proposed cuts to the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative.  Slashing GLRI’s annual budget would be devastating to efforts to preserve clean water, restore habitats, combat invasive species, and so much more. Our Great Lakes are an ecological treasure and an economic engine that must be defended. http://trib.in/2mf2Ljx

Yesterday, House Republicans’ debuted their bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Seven years in the making, the objectives – and consequences – come as no surprise. Instead of making care more affordable and accessible, Republicans have introduced fiscally irresponsible legislation that will expand subsidies for the wealthy and cut coverage from the working poor. This is not what the American people want or deserve. View my full statement on the American Health Care Act: http://bit.ly/2mirrYb

My staff and I are wearing red to show support for International Women’s Day and a #DayWithoutAWoman. All Americans, including our nation’s lawmakers, must recognize that women’s rights are human rights. Today, we thank and celebrate the strong women who have paved the way toward progress, while recommitting ourselves to the work that remains to secure equal pay, equal opportunities, and equal rights for all.

Today’s D+ rating from the American Society of Civil Engineers validates what we already knew: the condition of America’s infrastructure is unacceptable. At the same time, this report card highlights the importance and urgency of making long-term investments into projects that modernize, maintain, and advance our existing infrastructure systems. Investing in our connected infrastructure system is the key to improving quality of life, strengthening our economic competitiveness, and securing our leadership in a changing world. http://bit.ly/2mKHtex

Today, U.S. Environmental Protection AgencyAdministrator Scott Pruitt said he does not believe carbon dioxide is a primary contributor to global warming. Out of all the outrageous comments he has made about the existence of climate change, this may be the most misguided yet. The impacts of climate change effect us all, regardless of party affiliation, and so will the severe economic consequences of falling behind in the global transition to sustainable growth and a low-carbon energy future. We can’t risk lives and jeopardize livelihoods by denying scientific facts.
I will always speak out against efforts to undermine the safety and support of #transgender Americans.The United States is a place where everyone is welcome. #EveryoneWelcome

Today I visited with the Greater Chicago Food Depository as part of my "Undercover Congressman" initiative. It is important to raise awareness about the root causes of hunger and how strong community-based responses, like those led by GCFD, can lead to happier and healthier lives for our most vulnerable neighbors. Learn more about my visit:

The Trump Administration promised that repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act would make our nation a healthier, safer place for all. Once again, the reality is different than the rhetoric. How can any individual – Democrat or Republican – honestly say that this law would make Americans better off when it would leave 52 million without quality, affordable care by the year 2026? But these devastating impacts are not just a few years away; they are immense and immediate with an estimate of 14 million fewer being insured by next year alone. Today’s CBO scoring just highlights the consequences of prioritizing partisan games and political points over common-sense, bipartisan progress. Instead of weakening our health care, I stand ready to work with both parties to improve the Affordable Care Act and the essential coverage it provides to so many.

Yesterday, the Justice Department asked my committee, the House Intelligence Committee, for more time to provide evidence backing up President Trump's wiretapping claim.
